title: Runes reforged is garbage and creates more problems than it can ever solve.
body:
A major reason for damage currently being so high? Runes reforged.
Kleptomancy? Cancer
Commencing Stopwatch? BS, needed to be nerfed multiple times. Just another Gimmick.
Future's Market?  Lowkey overpowered
Relentless Hunter/Magical Footwear? Yay, more movement speed creep.
Adaptive AD/AP? Thank you for locking me into stats that I might not have wanted, so much for player/skill expression.
Second Wind/ Bone Plating? Thanks for making tanks even safer/stronger than they already are early game. So much for weak early in return for scaling.
Electrocute? Because thunderlords was sooo balanced.
Fleet of footwork? Aids.
Sorcery? Great, now damaging utility abilities pack just as much of a punch as straight damaging abilities.
Conquerers? Wow, it took half a year for Bruisers to get a rune that worked for them, and it still isn't even as good as the old Fervor. (Although Keystones had similar problems to runes reforged).

Literally the only good thing about Runes Reforged is that you no longer have to pay for it.
Outside of that, it's just enabled for even greater damage/mobility creep, and the choices honestly aren't even meaningful. The original Rune/Mastery system back in season 4 was more expressive.

Realistically, a smarter complaint is that it took a fine-grained system with lots of low-impact choices and replaced it with a system with only a few high impact choices, which left a lot of rough edges -- especially, at first, in some of the choices about what rune stats became champion base stats and which ones didn't. (The newfound extra damage that champions like Leona and Ezreal -- who deal a lot of magic damage but would've never taken mpen -- got from the removal of MR blues, for example, was an obvious initial problem.) 

If I wanted to complain about specific runes, Klepto seems like an easy target to bash because the level of RNG seemed excessive for a competitive game, regardless of how many controls got put on it, and it ultimately only became a top lane+ezreal rune even though it looked like it was supposed to be aimed at supports. 

All that being said, I'm personally glad we got runes reforged (the old runes system required stifling amounts of IP if you wanted optimal setups for multiple champions, and it also made it significantly harder to fill and offrole), but it's definitely less flexible than the old system, more volatile by design, and comes with its own set of problems (and arguably fewer levers to pull to fix them, since there are fewer rune choices now than there used to be rune+mastery choices -- though I imagine not having to hassle about IP refunds every time a rune gets removed or changed is very, very nice).  It was a large transition that was not handled perfectly and still has its issues even now, with a not-insignificant amount of champions stuck with suboptimal keystones, and some utter duds of keystones like Lethal Tempo. Still, the tradeoffs are much better for player QoL in the longterm, once these issues are ironed out. ...The issue is just getting them ironed out.

I'd say Runes Reforged is an amazing system in concept, (I love the UI and how easy it is to swap runes on the fly!) but in reality due to how certain runes and keystones interact with champion kits it tends to pick winners and losers, forcing builds and invalidating others.

I used to play a {{champion:432}} offtank build that feels quite ineffective right now. Largely, in part, due to no longer being able to stack armor/mr runes. Being able to acquire a ball of raw defensive stats from the old rune system was way, WAY more effective for the sustained defense I need/want than the current Keystones that (while interesting!) all tend to offer temporary, triggered effects that don't actually move the needle towards the 'offtank' role I'm aiming for.

Electrocute though? I can become an absolute damage beast, because it happens to mesh with his kit. It feels so forced by the rune system.

putting a satisfying amount of power into runes like was originally promised was (rightfully) rescinded, but now leaves us with a lot of little runes that feel shit or just aren't good. i've never really liked keystones since you started using them in s6, i feel like they take too much focus away from champion strengths and shift them towards "who can abuse the strongest keystones the best?" i don't think this changed in s8, either. i would rather have more of that interesting 'draw' runes initially have put into champ kits and new items

Personally I feel if riot was actually interested in approaching this topic they would have posted on one of the many well thought out and reasoned posts on this topic that pop up often. But of course riot only responds to the over the top abuse click baity posts, further fostering this kind of behavior.

You can however read one of the many thoughtful comments below about the short comings of the new system. Namely lack of choice, too heavy power warping balance.

Here's an opinion. Riot claimed that the choices you made with runes would alter how you play and not just be stat buffs/hidden power. I feel like the new runes have not delivered on that at all and im dissapointed.

>even greater damage/mobility creep

This is a recurring inquiry directed at the reds, but I'm not aware that it has been acknowledged or addressed. Can you address Riot's position on the cumulative effects of the following:

* keystone damage providing higher burst in shorter windows or on longer cooldowns than old mastery keystones (elec vs. TLD, PTA vs. Fervor)

* removal of MR runes increasing magic damage across the board on non-mpen users (eg Jax, Trist, Stattik Shiv, etc)

* season 8 buff to nerf ratio

* item changes with increased multipliers, including DCap, Rageblade, Sterak's

* relative increase in drake modifiers as a result of the above

The net effect has felt like damage has spiraled out of control this season. The side-effects of that are also familiar complaints:

* lower kill time increases the power of cc

* higher burst indirectly increases value of shields

* higher damage disproportionately advantages champs with innate durability, leading to complaints about tank duelists

* higher burst indirectly disadvantages low-burst champs

Comments or thoughts?

How about how the old system had lots of small choices and it was replaced with with a system with fewer choices, some of those aren't even applicable depending on the matchup. There are runes that some champions can't even use at all, further limiting choices. What happened to full AP rune pages or full crit rune pages. What happened to the fun of bringing weird combinations of runes to have 1000HP at level1 or lv 1 60% crit chance? You took a system which could be experimented with and threw it out so we could do what exactly? All have stopwatches for three months? Its not like the zhonyas effect was kept out of AD champions hands and gated behind an 800 gold combined cost for any tempo reasons at all ....  

Or how about how having stronger runes takes focus away from champion strengths and instead pushes the focus on the flat power everyone gets which homogenizes how games play out and detracts from the focus on the champions. 

Maybe a problem is that we were told that the choices we made with runes would alter how we play and not just be stat buffs/hidden power which many of them are. The runes system largely turned into a set of cookie cutter builds with little choice which was the exact problem you set out to solve in the first place and for all the dev time spent it doesn't feel like we've made gains in that direction. 

Another problem is that runes now give large amounts of on demand flat power in the early game which covers the weaknesses of late game scaling champions while also hyper-accentuating the oppressiveness of early game snowball champions. This has created a meta where you snowball the laning phase as quickly as possible leaving the enemy team too far behind to contest anything and just watching themselves slowly lose. Even scaling champions take this route because now they are lower risk early while still having high rewards for making it to mid/late game and snowballing the game the way masteries enable means they can hit late game very early. 

Of course all of this has been said many times over the past few years, but let's blame the OP for being frustrated that these issues haven't been addressed for years. Meanwhile you're here putting frustrated players in their place instead of reading the constructive posts on the issues which have already been made over and over again. Really shows your respect for these boards....

Tone aside, he has a point...which you've ignored. 

Since the keystone system was first introduced in season 6, I had thought this was the worst thing you could do to the mastery system - adding ludicrous damage and burst to already-bursty champions, restricting our freedom to experiment and/or change our builds to match our playstyles, and forcing us to find who can abuse the bullshit keystones better than others.  It meant that instead of choosing the masteries that could benefit our champions, it was choosing the champions that complimented the masteries since they added that much power and influence to them, while others went that entire 2 year period basically having no answer to those who could abuse their keystone more than they could.  

Turns out I was wrong.  You spent that whole period trying to fix something that was built broken, then you took everything you didn't learn from that update, and made something even worse in season 8 by adding EVEN MORE POWER to the game on top of the abysmal failure of the class updates which added more asinine damage, and then took away our means of defense by combining the runes and masteries into one giant clusterfuck of a bad idea.  Then consider how towers have (not) been changed over time, and we wonder why they're paper mache which leads to shorter lane phases, and we get a mastery for destroying them _faster??_ Gee, I wonder why games are being decided so soon this season.  Surely it's just player perception...

You think maybe it's because of the runes, the class updates, the gold income buffs, the minion pushing changes, the elemental dragons adding scaling power, the baron minion buffs, the item overhauls, or maybe the introduction of broken items that require constant updates?  Truth be told, it's all of this and more, but the Runes Reforged update is one of the primary reasons people are exploding again just like they were in season 6.  You want to reduce the damage?  Revert everything back to season 5's system, and give our real runes back.  You guys are making things extremely difficult for your balance team by continuing down this path, and it would benefit every party to go back to the system that didn't literally break everyone and everything it touched, and didn't give reasons to nerf specific champions into the ground just because they abused certain masteries, or to that point, masteries just because one champion abused them while their other users suffer because of it.  

The only problem with this is that you've wasted so much time and resources on this update that I assume going backwards would be heretical to bring up in a meeting.  It would be amusing to see your sycophants 180 and praise you for doing this after 2 and a half seasons of defending keystones though, just like they did when you stopped doing class reworks.

What I'm saying is that Runes Reforged is a flashy gimmick.
The flaws of the old (Prior to Keystones) Rune-page/Mastery system were blatant, Rune Pages and Runes were expensive, which gated choice and accessibility, especially for new players. There was nothing more painful than having to choose to buy a new Rune Page over a flashy new champion.

The Benefits of Runes Reforged is that it's completely free - you can edit your runes in champion select (something that people were asking for for years), so being forced to buy new rune pages for champion or build path variation is now a thing of the past.

The down side is that it's accelerated something that has been fatal to the meta and enjoy-ability of many games - damage creep. 

The final mastery available in the old Rune System's offensive tree was Havoc, which allowed for 3% damage amplification. Compare that to today's Thunderlord, which allows for 50-220 base damage + 50% bonus ad or 30% AP, and it becomes painstakingly easily to see why people on boards are constantly complaining about damage being too high. Especially when you consider that some other Keystones grant as much, if not even more damage depending on the champions kit.

You could argue that that's offset by the introduction of runes such as Summon Aery and other defensive masteries. But now we've landed in a precarious situation where Runes Reforged now has a sizeable impact on the balance of the game. The old Runes/Masteries were important, yes, but very rarely so important that champions actually had to be balanced around them. Now, however, Riot has to embark on the delicate task of balancing champions, itemisation, and Runes Reforged all at once  - because if one falls out of sync, you end up with things such a pre-nerf Klepto GP top.
Another example of this is Bruisers, who fell out of favour massively and required a new Rune to be introduced just for them. (and even then, you can still argue that their needs still aren't being entirely met since, as I'm sure you're aware, the balance of Top Lane is still a much complained about issue)
Or even champions such as Fiddlesticks who, with the jungle changes and Runes Reforged changes, simply can't function as they once could. He relies on sustain so the universal increase in burst, as well as the fact that there isn't really a rune that he truly synergises with, has left Fiddlesticks mains wanting. 

And this is just a focus on the Keystones, the secondary Runes are arguably even more of a problem.
Runes such as Bone Plating, Second Wind, Mana Flow Band and Commencing Stop Watch have really only served to minimise the weaknesses that were imposed on them by the previous balance team while accentuating their strengths, but in turn limiting skill expression. 
For example, commencing stopwatch had to be nerfed multiple times because it negatively impacted on the meaningful choices that an early game champion, or early game focused role could make. I remember one Korean clip where a fight broke out at level 4 botlane with like 8 people involved,and nearly every single one of them used stop-watch and essentially made the plays made by the other teams meaningless. Similarly, with it, a champion such as Orianna could double-down on her advantage as a notoriously safe-pick, and effectively become immune to the engages of assassins such as Zed or Talon - with a single rune meaningful agency has been taken from them. Meanwhile Mana flow band for some reason allows Mana champions to spam their abilities without hesitation...so Orianna who was once gaited by mana now isn't, and is effectively pseudo-resource-less, now agency has been removed in two ways. Commencing Stopwatch removes the reward of targeting her health pool, while Manaflow band prevents you from fighting with her resource bar. 
I'm not using this as an example to specifically point the finger at Orianna as something that's balanced/imbalanced...but this kind of distortion of what should be meaningful strengths and weaknesses of champions/classes can be seen throughout Runes Reforged, such as certain runes negating the weak early that tanks traditionally should suffer from, which is honestly bad balance since such trends are not only frustrating to play against, but can also require for target nerfing of certain champions or items because they synergise too well, even though they are otherwise balanced.

As for Kleptomancy, why Riot would introduce an RNG rune when they've historically had trouble balancing other RNG mechanics such as Dodge and Crit (Dodge was rightfully removed, and Crit has been complained about basically since its inception) is beyond me. 

I don't want to type anymore.

The new runes are good, however they leave so, so, so many holes that the old system filled.
Stacking armor, MR, HP, %HP, or my favorite full scaling AD illaoi. There's just no alternative to these. Not even close, it's as whelming as picking a mastery page now that the initial excitement has worn off. 

In certain ways it most definitely does cause more balance issues than the old system ever could, but that's because you felas tried to make it interesting and to do that make it more complicated or have more components. But interest only lasts so long, and now it's so more engaging or interesting than the old rune system. 
It's back to where we always arrive at, cookie cutter builds that everyone will use  unless they come up with something almost as good and can rely on their skill to close the gap between it and the superior choice

I have complaints about the rune system, but in my experience cookie cutter builds is not a major problem. It might be the champs I play, but thus far I've found a lot of build variety in the new rune system. For example:

{{champion:143}} Currently running Dom/Precision, but Zyra players regularly run any combination of the trees with any combination of secondary. Even Aftershock is a viable situational keystone for the resist buff against high-burst teams. I'll even pick up Fleet Footwork against hard poke/sustain lanes like Xerath, Vlad, or Cassio.

Actually, almost every champ I play has 3-4 options for main keystone choice and another 1-2 for situational picks.

While runes and masteries always shape the game, now more than ever it feels like you are playing the runes. Not the characters, but the runes.
Runes reforged is the best thing that happened to this game
